page.title: 03LAND USE _ FORESTRY
page.content: This area is the more mature part of the forest. The land in was bought by the forestry commission in 1926 having been previously owned by the Lairds of Pitfour _ the Fergusons. The first plantings took place in 1930. The trees being the Sitka Spruce from Alaska. Apparently these are well_suited to exposure, and, in particular are most resistant to the prevailing wind which is westerly and causing most damage. Minor species of trees which have followed the first plantings are the Norway Spruce, Japanese Larch and the Lodgepoll Pine (American). The Sitka Spruce reaches maturity after fifty years. The first fellings were in the 1970's. After two years more trees are planted and the mature trees are felled leaving room for future planting. This is the usual pattern of rotation.
